title: RS21342
content: The diversity visa lottery encourages legal immigration from countries other than major sending countries to the US. It allocates immigrant visas based on family ties and employment needs. The program was added to the Immigration Act of 1990 to promote new and varied migration. The lottery began in FY1995 and offers 55,000 visas annually to countries with low immigrant admissions in the past five years. The diversity lottery allocates 55,000 visas annually to countries with low immigrant admissions in the past five years. Visas are divided among six geographic regions based on population, with a limit of 7% per country. Recipients become legal permanent residents of the US. The program has not been directly amended since its inception in 1990. The diversity lottery allocates 55,000 visas annually to countries with low immigrant admissions in the past five years, divided among six regions. Recipients become legal permanent residents of the US. The Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act temporarily reduces the annual ceiling by up to 5,000 visas. In FY2002, 42,829 persons were admitted or adjusted as LPRs with diversity visas, representing 4% of all LPRs that year. In FY2002, 42,829 persons were admitted or adjusted as Legal Permanent Residents (LPRs) with diversity visas, representing 4% of all LPRs that year. The top five countries for diversity visa recipients were Albania, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Poland, and Ukraine. Albania has consistently been the top sending country for diversity visas. In the mid-1990s, Poland and the former Soviet Union were top winners of diversity visas, but their participation has declined. Albania is the leading sending country, followed by Nigeria. Russia and Ukraine's numbers may be underestimated due to reporting issues. Diversity visa recipients from Europe and Africa are significantly higher compared to family-based and employment-based immigrants. European immigrants comprised 39.4% of diversity visa recipients, while African immigrants received 38.1%. To be eligible for a diversity visa, an alien must have a high school education or two years of relevant experience. Winners must come from countries listed for the diversity visa lottery and undergo reviews before entering the United States. The diversity visa lottery winners must have a high school education or two years of relevant experience and be from eligible countries. They undergo reviews by Department of State consular officers and DHS inspectors to ensure they meet visa requirements and are not ineligible for entry based on various grounds for inadmissibility. The State Department announced the FY2005 lottery on August 19, 2003, with a 60-day application period starting in November. The FY2005 diversity visa lottery was announced by the State Department on August 19, 2003, with a 60-day application period starting on November 1, 2003. Applications had to be submitted electronically, and certain countries were ineligible for the lottery, including Canada, China, Colombia, Dominican Republic, and others. In FY2005, certain countries like Canada, China, Colombia, and others were ineligible for the diversity visa lottery. Applicants had to follow State Department instructions precisely to avoid disqualification. Over 2 million applications in FY2003 were disqualified for not complying with instructions. Multiple applications from the same alien are disqualified, but spouses can submit separate entries. In FY2005, spouses and unmarried children under 21 can submit separate entries for the diversity visa lottery. Derivative beneficiaries must be listed on the petition, and their visas count against the cap. If a winner dies before obtaining LPR status, the visa is revoked. Winners are selected randomly by computer, and notifications are expected between May and July 2004. Visas will be issued between October 1, 2004, and September 30, 2005. The State Department is expected to notify winners of the FY2005 diversity lottery by mail between May and July 2004. Visas will be issued between October 1, 2004, and September 30, 2005. Winning the lottery does not guarantee a visa, as more applications are received than visas available. Applicants must act quickly to submit necessary documentation by September 30, 2005. In-person interviews are expected to start in October 2004. Some question the continuation of the lottery, preferring the 55,000 visas be used for family members waiting years for visas to immigrate to the United States. Some question the continuation of the diversity visa lottery, preferring visas be used for backlog reduction in other categories. Supporters argue that the diversity visa provides new immigrants and balances the immigration system dominated by family-based immigrants. Critics suggest amending the INA to exclude nationals from terrorism-sponsoring countries from the lottery due to security concerns. The United States is considering excluding nationals from terrorism-sponsoring countries from the diversity visa lottery due to security concerns. Supporters argue for the current law to be uniformly applied, while the issue of who should bear the costs of operating the lottery has also been raised. The diversity visa has been criticized for being vulnerable to fraud and misuse, but the State Department is addressing these concerns.
